hobby.message: Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Feels more silent, if that's possible.
I used to walk for street shots—analog camera, you know.
Last week even that felt risky with the patrols off-sync.
Some things don't get easier just because it's cold.
Colder, yeah. People dodge each other's eyes now.
I shoot street photos—all film, pretty old-school of me.
Evenings are best for catching the right shadows, or they used to be.
Since Halden died, I've noticed more static drones blocking normal routes.
Makes getting a real shot harder, but I keep trying.
Definitely colder, not just the air.
I like to shoot analog photos around the city, old 35mm film.
There's this sweet spot when dusk hits Yellow Market—used to be my favorite.
Lately, everything’s off—transport failures, drones acting weird, even foot traffic feels rehearsed.
My last roll, I nearly got locked out at two checkpoints for no reason.
Feels like the city itself is spooked, and so am I.
Colder everywhere, even in places I used to love for street photos.
Not digital—real film, old Minolta, capturing faces no algorithm can.
Last week, after Halden’s death? The atmosphere changed fast.
System bugs stalled transit, patrols felt blind but hyper-alert at the same time.
I got a perfect shot of a kid bartering bread, but swapped film in a stairwell, shaking.
Now I archive rolls at home, just in case the index starts noticing my patterns.
Small risks, but real ones, every time I go out now.
It’s not just cold, it’s like the city is holding its breath.
I shoot analog street photos—film can’t be edited by the compliance index.
My dad worked for BCI, so I learned where cameras are blind.
After Halden died, everything glitched—dead drones, error lights, ghosts in the system.
That last evening in Yellow Market, even regulars acted strange; a maintenance bot just stared at me.
I caught a real moment: contraband trade, bread for ration slips, but my hands shook changing film.
Half my contacts avoid me now—paranoid, or flagged. I save every negative locally.
Some days I wonder if each shot might be my last, til things shift again.
hobby_answer: Survived, sure. Not easy to find good light now.
Stopped by the market, whole place felt dead.
Everyone’s tense since Halden—streets are watched, too many eyes.
Used half a roll, won’t risk the rest yet.
Still shooting, barely—risky these days.
Yellow Market had real moments, but security’s thicker now.
Halden's gone, and the checks are glitchy, unpredictable.
Film’s hard to hide with all these delays.
Thinking about pausing until this blows over.
Yeah, the Minolta made it out today, just barely.
Halden’s death made the networks glitch—tram lines stalled, cameras frozen.
Shot a few frames at dusk, but people noticed.
City bots stand still now, not scanning—feels wrong.
Feels like every photo is being watched, even if the cameras are blank.
Saved the negatives, but I’m more careful with every shot.
Streets don’t forgive mistakes right now.
Survived, though not without a few scares.
Spent two hours at the market after Halden’s announcement—whole place is off-balance.
My Minolta’s nearly caught at a security sweep. Never used to happen.
Error lights on city cams now make me more nervous than green.
Ended early because a maintenance bot zeroed in on me.
Swapped film hiding in a stairwell—that adrenaline ruins the frame.
Every photo feels heavier—like evidence, not art.
Missing Halden, the city misses routine. Even the shadows feel watched.
Minolta survived, but I’m not sure I did.
Used to know every blind spot in Yellow Market—now I can’t trust any of them.
After Halden’s death, AI glitches left doors locked, alerts blaring. Even the drones act lost.
Got stuck between two patrol sweeps—risked losing more than a negative.
Had to swap film in a half-lit stairwell, hands shaking. Reminded me of those old raids my father whispered about.
That night, every photo was a gamble—crowd eyes on me, not just the cameras.
People look away now, no one wants to be in the frame.
Makes you realize, catching real life on film is defiance these days.
No digital filter, no edits—just the city staring back, unblinking. That’s why I do it.
